description: Borrowed from Latin excrēmentum, from excernō (“I excrete”).

entries.meaning: (now specifically) Human and animal solid waste excreted from the bowels; feces.
(archaic) Any waste matter excreted from the human or animal body, or discharged by bodily organs.
examples: A French Gentleman was ever wont to blow his nose in his hand […]. He asked me on a time, what privilege this filthie excrement had, that wee should have a daintie linnen cloth or handkercher to receive the same.

description: Borrowed from Latin excrēmentum, from excrēscō (“I grow out”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Something which grows out of the body; hair, nails etc.
